description.narrative: The new WATCH 24/7  aims to respond to OSEC by 1) increasing the capacity of Law Enforcement to PROSECUTE perpetrators by adopting new online forensics tools and strengthening government reporting mechanisms; 2) improving the quality of service PROVISION to victims of OSEC both directly and indirectly by building the capacity of government services.

title.narrative: Government child protection services are supported and gain capacity to apply social work and alternative care minimum standards to provide effective victim assistance.

description.narrative: Government child protection services are supported and gain capacity to apply social work and alternative care minimum standards to provide effective victim assistance.

comment.narrative: 22 new children received assistance. In total 28 (26 girls) were assisted in Q4. (Link to 3.1.2) -8 (8F) APLE -09 (7F) Auscam -10 (10F) Hope for Justice -1 (1F) Hagar;

By this reporting period, 34 (27 girls) child victims were identified from existing and new cases of OCSE by partner and sub-partners. The victims have received different services according to their needs including emergency assistance/package and psychosocial/emotional counselling, legal counselling before and during their participation in criminal proceedings at police and court stages and their families of OCSE cases and themselve were referred to receive psycho-social support to NGOs;

There were uncertainties during Q2 as to how to implement this outcome. By the end of the quarter, the PM proposed to develop sub-agreements with 3 to 5 NGO service providers, which is being processed for a start in August.;

title.narrative: Government child protection services facilitate access to quality rehabilitation and reintegration services

description.narrative: Government child protection services facilitate access to quality rehabilitation and reintegration services

title.narrative: Number of Children Receiving Rehabilitation and Reintegration Services

description.narrative: Number of Children Receiving Rehabilitation and Reintegration Services

comment.narrative: By project sub partners, 2 existing clients by Hagar were reintegrated home facilitated by government officer and 15 clients admitted to HFJ transitional center received a holistic support package of safe place, food, bedding, clothing, toiletries, psychological assessment and individual and group counselling/therapy sessions, life-skill and child protection lessons, catch up education, legal support and play/recreation and plan for reintegration. 9 victims by APLE also received the services and were referred for reintegration services.;
ToR under development - same as above;
same as above.;

title.narrative: Government social workers facilitate access to emergency support and referral

description.narrative: Government social workers facilitate access to emergency support and referral

comment.narrative: 2 girls victims were rescued by APLE in this quarter. APLE has supported police to investigate the suspects and support the victims with legal aid and referral for psychosocial support.;
5 girls victims were rescued by APLE in this quarter. APLE has supported police to investigate the suspect and support the victims for needs services.;

Legal aid will be provided by APLE as this activity is included in the new partnership agreement. Emergency support will be provided by sub-partners / service providers (same as above). a ToR is being developed to clarify roles and responsibilities with regards to victim referral, intake and technical assistance to be provided by TDHNL. It was too risky to start without this agreement.;

title.narrative: LEA investigate OCSE files leading to the arrest ot child abusers

description.narrative: LEA investigate OCSE files leading to the arrest ot child abusers

comment.narrative: 15 suspects under investigation by the anti-human trafficking police with support from APLE.;

As a project partner, APLE initially investigated and assisted Cambodia National Police in the investigation of 13 OCSE cases. Majority of the cases are being investigated by police; one of the suspects was arrested. (Link to activity 2.2.2);
Same as above - postponed to Q3;

comment.narrative: no training was provided (see above).;
same as above, no tool identified. the cost that appears is related to the legal assessment conducted by an external consultant in Q2.;
same as above;

title.narrative: Law enforcement agencies have an increased capacity to investigate OCSE by adopting new forensic tools

description.narrative: Law enforcement agencies have an increased capacity to investigate OCSE by adopting new forensic tools

comment.narrative: the consultations with the LEA stakeholders could not start in Q2 because of the uncertainties regarding the development and use of the Sweetie 3.0 tool;
there was no new forensic tool introduced, as CO team waiting for decision following the country-level legal assessments.;
there were no new tools introduced as TDH decided not to provide those.;

title.narrative: Law enforcement receive support to investigate cases of OCSE identified through IT forensic tools and and through established local and national reporting mechanisms.

description.narrative: Law enforcement receive support to investigate cases of OCSE identified through IT forensic tools and and through established local and national reporting mechanisms.

title.narrative: Number of Child Abusers Stopped and Tracked

description.narrative: Number of Child Abusers Stopped and Tracked

comment.narrative: 13 investigations on suspected OCSE, slow process because LEA and courts do not have tools in place and minimizing risks of this form of exploitation.;
The partnership agreement with APLE was completed and signed in July. Therefore there is no progress for Q2.;

While a relatively high number of reports were received by project partners, OCSE investigations remain very challenging to take forward because of insufficient technical capacities and only 1 suspect was arrested.;

title.narrative: Reporting mechanisms at the national and local levels are improved to identify OCSE

description.narrative: Reporting mechanisms at the national and local levels are improved to identify OCSE

comment.narrative:
98 potential OCSE cases were reported through phone hotlines, the INHOPE Internet hotline, screening surveys, local authorities and project partners. The reports cases involved CSAM, Online grooming, Live streaming, and Sextortion and other concerns on OCSE. Relevant cases were referred to law enforcement for investigation, partner NGOs for social and legal services, reported through the INHOPE ICCAM system and to domain owners for notice and takedown of sexual abuse contents. Reports per partner: -47 APLE -40 AUSCAM -10 Hope for Justice -0 This Life Cambodia -1 Hagar
Overspending for Q4 is due to the delay in implementation (catching up from Q2 ans Q3);

By this quarter, APLE has received 52 OCSE cases through it Internet hotline, local authorities and project partners i.e. Auscam. The reports received were related to CSAM, online solicitation, sexting, sextortion, grooming and others which was related to follow up and non- actionable cases. Underspending due to delays in identifying service provider to test IT solution to increase reporting and cancellation of in-person meetings with LEA.;
postponed to Q3;
